text: thank you everyone for coming really excited to be here and to share a bit of my experience and also maybe help some
of you get started with extending kubernetes and becoming a kubernetes developer I've been to a few talks so
far here that have been talking about some of the more advanced aspects of creating controllers and creating
operators and I think from my perspective not long ago I hadn't even gotten started so I didn't know what
that all was and I'd like to lower that barrier of Entry through this tutorial today
so I talk about becoming a kubernetes developer but that's not a common term I
don't think I mean I think some people might use it but not sure what the definition is right now and I think about that because I think
of three different interaction models that you might have with kubernetes you might be a user you might be someone who
has their application deployed to kubernetes and you have access to cube
CTL on the CLI or maybe you don't maybe you have a user interface in some way that you access your deployment and your
logs and look at things you may even be an advanced user just to say but you're still someone who
considers kubernetes a place to run your software you may be in the room and you may be an
administrator an administrator might be someone who creates clusters on demand for their organization they might do
some configuration of those clusters and may run some software themselves this would be software that would support the
organization so things like monitoring applications Prometheus other tools that
you might need this is likely to be someone who's a bit more advanced within cubectl but and
other techniques but someone who's really focused on the infrastructure side of kubernetes
and what we're going to be focusing on today is the developer side so this is someone who may or may not also be or
used to be a user and administrator but it's someone who thinks about kubernetes as an API and a framework and a way to
solve problems and so what they do is they use kubernetes native aspects to extend that API and use that
API to solve their business problems and that's what we're going to be looking at a bit today
and so you might wonder which one am I I've been and am all three I started my
career in test engineering and was very much on the user side of things I went into platform engineering and was a part
of infrastructure teams for a few years there and I was very much an administrator and I'm now building a
controller running inside of kubernetes and I'm very much on the developer side of things
and so by being all three of these things both in recent history as well as simultaneously the reason I'm excited to
share this is because I found that barrier to getting started to be a developer just a bit too high I just
kind of was like where do I get started everything seems really Advanced I need to be super advanced in goaling to even
look at anything and I'm not particularly a goaling developer and I think that now there's some really great
tooling out there to get people started and that's what we're going to look at today so when I keep talking about today what
are we going to do in the next 90 minutes we have 90 minutes and we have conference Wi-Fi so just setting expectations uh but what
we're going to be doing is I'm going to do a very short introduction about what an operator is and how and why you might
choose to use one that's just going to be kind of surface level about extensions in that way then
we're going to have a bit over an hour hopefully of kind of Hands-On self-paced time we're going to be using an online
learning platform which means that we're only reliant on the website loading and not downloading Docker images and
configuring your laptops you don't need admin access or anything like that but you're gonna have a lot of time
there uh for like kind of self-paced learning and at the end of it you will be you will have created a create read
update and delete or crud uh operator that deploys an application can update
it and can delete it so you have the framework to then go back to your companies and extend that into your own
worlds so getting started with what is extending kubernetes here's a diagram
that is on the kubernetes like websites and documentation and it shows all the
points where you can extend kubernetes because it is open source and you can extend and you can rewrite anywhere
but realistically most people using kubernetes value the engineers behind it and value the decisions that they've
made so they only tend to extend in in certain areas more frequently
so let's explore a few of those options one option is at the CLI so I've
mentioned Kube CTL Cube cuddle I'm sure there's a lot of people judging me right now sorry but this is going to be most
people's entry point to kubernetes and what you can do here is you can build command line tools off of an already
existing CLI that people are used to crew is a fantastic way to manage these
plugins so maybe you can think about not creating a whole new CLI that people need to install and configure but
instead look to extend it through the marketplace on crew if you haven't used crew before give it a look there's some
really nice Tools in there some of my favorites are the most basic they're things like grep and a proper get all if
you've ever run Kube CTL get all and then like but where's everything else there's a plug-in and crew that actually
gets all and it's it's really great so that's one place where you might think about becoming a kubernetes developer
and think about extending kubernetes moving down the stack you might think
about creating custom resource definitions or crds this is a resource type that you probably have interacted
with in kubernetes before as a user and admin or or anything else and all it is
is it lets you define an interface it lets you define a resource type I'm not going to go too much into detail
here because this is what we're going to actually one of the things we're going to be doing here today and so if you haven't worked with crds before you're
going to get a great introduction to them one more layer down you might think
about actually running software and extending uh using the API and events API within kubernetes and that is us
talking about the operator framework which is what we're going to be working on with the operator framework you can be
listening to kubernetes events on and changes in the cluster and taking reactions accordingly again I'm not
going to go into great detail here because this is what we're going to be talking about and you're going to be doing a lot with in just a few moments
the final bit that I would just call out as maybe a common place to see extensions is sort of what's on like the
node level and infrastructure level so CSI is looking at the container storage and how you can add access to
third-party storage items ability to get through to databases out in the cloud and SAS
providers and things like that so these are just a few of the ways in which you can extend kubernetes that you
may run into as you start to explore potentials uh the the text of where to
find these is very small and vertical on the side but all these slides are already up on the kubecon website and so
you can go there check that out and they have fantastic spidering links that you can get into rabbit holes Galore on so
it was really great to see so if we want to talk about operators today we have to start with controllers
what is a controller a controller is an application that runs inside of your kubernetes cluster and takes something
that is uh defined as true and checks that that is what's actually happening
in reality and the controller's job is to take what is defined as desirable and
slowly but eventually get us to that state in reality
you actually have more experience probably with controllers than you might think because if you've ever been if
you've ever used a deployment to deploy your application you've actually used a controller
a deployment controller watches for a deployment resource type and if and when the deployment resource
type is different from what is really existing in the cluster it makes the changes
it changes the replica set and then in turn it will change the uh the the pods
that are deployed so I prefer working examples so here's an example you might have a deployment
out there that already exists that has two replicas quite common and you might want to increase your
replicas you've gotten quite popular and so you increase to three replicas what happens is the deployment
controller is aware of this change and goes hmm that's not what reality is let
me go and create a third pod and then it just goes back to sleep and it hangs out for a while until something
else comes along that's all that a controller does is it checks what is Define State what is
reality State and it is configured to be able to con to uh Converge on the
desired state so you're in a tutorial about operators and
I'm talking about controllers the reason I am is because it's a bit like squares and rectangles all
rectangle all squares are types of rectangles but not all rectangles are squares every operator under the hood is a type
of controller it takes the desired state it converges it into the reality State
not all operators are not all controllers are operators so now it's
important to look at what that difference is what is an operator an operator is that representation of
operational knowledge into the controller into that ability to converge
on desired to reality state and reliably manage it I've here
pictured Argo as an example of a tool that has an operator that you may want
to check out you may already use there's lots of operators out there there's an entire operator Hub where you can check
out what tools provide these what an operator is it's actually just a
package of resources within kubernetes it includes those custom resource definitions or crds it includes
deployments Services whatever you need to be able to use that application
so with the operator there's a capability model that describes how
mature that operator is when it comes to operations level one being it can deploy the thing
this is what we're going to be talking about mostly today but there's so much more to operations and it's why this is
a really interesting model if you're thinking about that day two operations of your application and how you want to
handle that as a platform team as an operations team and so on

actually create a controller an API and each of these applications can have more

what make run does is it gives us a really fast way to be able to iterate on
development so when you think about building any website you don't the the first thing you do is not package it up
into a Docker image push it out to a registry push it through CI CD and straight into an environment because the
feedback loop for that is quite large what you want to be able to do is make a change see that change locally validate
that it looks about right and then go through the efforts of a CI CD pipeline
to then test it in a more realistic environment make run is the local development
version of working with your controller and Cube Builder make run takes that
goaling application and runs it on your local computer with access to your kubernetes cluster where all the
